abstracts.cdata!:
The Multi-Sector AIDS program Project
            for Malawi will contribute to the reduction of the HIV/AIDS
            prevalence and reduce the impacts of HIV/AIDS on the
            infected and affected people, through a community and
            multisectoral approach. The project anticipates several
            impacts. The institutional and legal framework is weak, the
            Health Care Waste Management (HCWM) is not a priority in the
            national health policy, and the institutional framework
            lacks a strategic plan, clear responsibilities, specific
            guidelines, and procedures in HCWM. Absence of reliable data
            on amount of waste produced, inadequate pre-collection,
            collection, and storage of containers, unsustainable HCW
            treatment systems, and inadequate financial resources.
            Hospital staff, collection staff, scavengers, and people
            using recycled objects come into direct contact with HCW and
            are liable to HIV/AIDS contamination. The general public
            needs information about the dangers related to the materials
            collected. Lack of external transportation of HCW
            constitutes a major constraint for health centers. Solid
            waste management suffers from lack of financial support from
            the state and local governments. The objectives for the
            prevention and mitigation plan include a plan to reduce
            infections due to HCW, improve service in HCWM, and
            establish a well-managed multi-sector institutional
            framework for coordination and implementation of HCWM measures.
